speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)) moved
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
that Bill C-55, an act to amend certain acts in relation to pensions and to enact the Special Retirement Arrangements Act and the Pension Benefits Division Act, be read the second time and referred to Legislative Committee G.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to begin the debate on Bill C-55, an act to amend certain acts in relation to pensions and to enact the Special Retirement Arrangements Act and the Pension Benefits Division Act.
This bill is an important step in the evolution of the various pension plans in the federal Public Service. It responds to a number of long-standing concerns of plan members and fulfils the government's announced intention to ensure its pension programs observe the same income tax actuals as those imposed on other employers' pension plans.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
I refer to this bill as a step in the evolution of our pension plans because there are still important issues relating to these programs that remain to be reviewed. Many hon. members will be aware of these.
There are concerns expressed by employees and pensioners about their role in the management of their plans and the investment of the pension funds, with the resulting effects on the return earned by the pension account.

The Auditor General has also suggested that these matters need further study and that the implications of the internal funding of Public Service pension arrangements be more fully assessed in terms of their impact on the management of public debt.
The members of the pension plans have also indicated that they would like to revisit many aspects of the design of these plans, and we agree that the adequacy and appropriateness of elements such as survivor benefits, disability benefits, co-ordination of these programs with the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans, vesting and portability should be reviewed in the context of the changes that have taken place in the work force, career patterns, and standards and practices of other employers since the current legislation was enacted by Parliament.

While these issues are obviously of great concern to the plan members, both employees and pensioners must recognize our responsibilities to the other stakeholders, the Canadian taxpayers. These important stakeholders expect us to ensure that the financial commitments we make to Public Service pension arrangements on their behalf are both reasonable and fair. It is important, therefore, as we look at the bill before us today, to bear in mind that the government considers these proposals as addressing only some of the most pressing problems with the pensions plans.
At the same time work is continuing on other issues that are also of concern but which may lead to more fundamental revisions to the nature of these programs.

I plan to meet with my advisory committee on the Public Service Superannuation Act veiy shortly to seek their views on critical issues related to pensions for the federal Public Service. The committee, which includes
members from unions, senior management and the Federal Superannuates National Association, will be asked to advise me and the government on what they view as fair and appropriate solutions to long-term issues. Similar committees will be established for the Canadian Forces and RCMP Superannuation Acts under the proposals contained in Bill C-55.
Hon. members will be aware that the pension plan for members of Parliament has come under particular scrutiny by the public. The government will be re-examining all elements of this plan, including those features which have been criticized by some as too generous. In this examination we will welcome and take account of the views of hon. members who can personally attest to the importance of this element as part of their overall compensation package. Some of you have told me that the pension plan was a critical part of their decision to seek elected office.
At the same time I know that hon. members share my concern that some members of the public have criticized the current pension plan as too far out of line with general practice.

To be credible, a review of parliamentary pension arrangements must also provide for specific input from the public. I have already indicated that the views of those independent of Parliament will be actively solicited in this study.
Returning to the matter currently before this House, I would like to review the major provisions of the bill to indicate their impact and the government's rationale for the proposals.
Bill C-55, as its title suggests, would amend a number of existing statutes, principally the Public Service Superannuation Act, the Canadian Forces Superannuation Act, the RCMP Superannuation Act and the Members of Parliament Retiring Allowances Act.
It also proposes the enactment of two new statutes, the first being a special retirement arrangements act which would permit revision to the existing plans as they apply to non-career diplomats and lieutenant-governors. As well, this act would provide for the establishment of a new type of plan for those covered under all those statutes except that applicable to members of Parliament.
February 24, 1992



The second new act proposed is the Pension Benefits Division Act dealing with the division of pension benefits on marriage breakdown. As well, there are related and consequential amendments required to the older Defence Services and RCMP Pension Continuation Acts and the Supplementary Retirement Benefits Act.
Essentially the proposed legislation would put in place measures of two general sorts: first, some proposed measures where the government has indicated for some time its wish to move forward and where further delay would cause continued difficulty for members of the plans and their families; and, second, a number of measures to ensure that federal public sector plans comply with requirements imposed on all pension plans by changes to the Income Tax Act in 1989 and given full effect by regulations promulgated in January of this year under that act.

These tax changes were designed to ensure that all Canadians would have equal opportunities to benefit from tax assistance for retirement savings, whether those savings are made individually or as a member of an employer sponsored pension plan.
Clearly it is the government's view that those plans which the federal government sponsors as employer ought to meet the same legislation which applies to others.
Accordingly, Bill C-55 proposes revisions to each of the pension statutes to ensure they provide for pension plans that can continue to be registered under the Income Tax Act for purposes of tax relief on employee contributions.
Achieving this tax compliance means that in all of the programs, some elements can no longer be provided as part of the registered pension plan.
A simple example of this would be the Income Tax Act provision limiting the maximum pension to be accrued under a pension plan to $1,722 for each year of plan membership. Under the federal programs, this limit is not specified. It is necessary to incorporate the limit in
Government Orders
each of the statutes by limiting the level of salary on which benefits can be based.

Imposing these and other limits in accordance with tax law on the basic pension plan would result in reduced pension coverage for certain employees. However, given that it is not uncommon for other employers to provide for retirement income arrangements that go beyond the tax prescribed maximum, and given that fundamental review of these pension plans is still under way, the government has concluded that it is appropriate to continue the present pension arrangements. This would be accomplished in the same way as it is for employers in the private sector by providing for benefits outside those that can be provided under the registered pension plans through a separate arrangement permitted by the Income Tkx Act.
For all plans but that for members of Parliament, this would be done by regulations to be made under the proposed new Special Retirement Arrangements Act. These regulations would permit the current pension plan to continue to provide for employee and employer contributions to be made to a new fund to be known as the Retirement Compensation Arrangements Account. For members of Parliament, the retirement compensation arrangement would be provided in the statute itself.

The term retirement compensation arrangement or RCA is used by the Income Tax Act with reference to funds established by an employer that are in the hands of a third party to provide for future retirement income for their employees.
While an employer and employees may claim a tax deduction for contributions to such a fund, the custodian of the fund must pay tax on all revenues to the fund. The tax is refundable as benefits are paid out of the plan. The effect is that benefits provided this way are more costly than those provided under the registered plan.
While the federal government is obviously not a tax paying employer, we felt it was important to provide the RC approach for benefits outside those which can be provided under the tax registered pension plan.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
Why? First of all, it is felt essential that there be recognition in the national accounts of Canada of the future obligation to employees for their own pensions.
It is also considered important that the government not take advantage of its status as a non-taxable employer and as a government to provide employees with compensation at lower cost levels that would not be available to other employers.
The over-all effect of the bill's proposals would be to ensure that pension costs are fully known to Canadians and comparable to those of other employers who provide similar arrangements.
I realize that this discussion of the tax compliance initiative has been somewhat technical, but it is vital to understand that the government has every intention of complying with its own rules and that we are not taking advantage of our unique position as a non-taxing employer and the maker of the rules.
At the same time the members of these pension plans should be assured that the government is not using this requirement as an excuse to alter the retirement income arrangements they rely on.

There is another aspect of this bill which would apply to all the existing plans and to the new arrangements I have just described. The bill also proposes that all plans should henceforth be operated on a fully funded basis, that is the credits made to the various pension accounts in the form of ongoing employee and employer contributions should be at levels which, together with the anticipated future interest earnings, would be adequate to provide for the future benefits of the employees as they are being earned.
As part of this initiative, the contributions that are now being made to the supplementary retirement benefits account by employees and employer would henceforth be made to the relevant superannuation account. The balances in the supplementary retirement benefits account related to each of the pension plans would also be transferred to the main pension accounts. Basic pensions and indexing of pensions would be unchanged and would then be paid from this combined account.

Employee contribution rates would remain at the same level. The government would contribute at the
level necessary to maintain full advance funding of accruing benefits.
Provision is also made that any existing or future unfunded liabilities associated with these plans would be recognized and amortized by additional government contributions.
The effect of these changes and the financial arrangements would be that all pension obligations relating to each sector would be recognized in one plan, thus consolidating the assets and obligations in respect of each group. This would clarify the financial situation of the programs and make sure they operate on a basis that is consistent with private sector standards. The full funding of all benefits would also help to reassure employees and pensioners about the security of their benefits.

Some other aspects of this bill that are of significant impact on the members of some or all plans would be viewed very positively by those who are affected. These are the changes that I have characterized as fairness improvements. They will surely be welcomed by those affected, and the government does not wish to delay them any longer.
The first of these relates to the provision in the Public Service Superannuation Act of the opportunity for persons employed on a part-time basis to benefit from pension coverage, if they choose. To date, Mr. Speaker, as you know, only those working 30 or more hours per week contribute. All employees who are employed to work more than 12 hours per week on average would now qualify to contribute.
Those who are so employed when the provision takes effect would have the option to elect not to join the plan, but future part-time appointees would be required to contribute.

This is a significant step in allowing individuals to reconcile their personal and work commitments without jeopardizing their long-term retirement situation. It would give effect to a government commitment in the white paper on PS 2000. The bill also proposes that plan members be allowed to elect to make additional contributions in order to count prior part-time employment as pensionable service if such employment occurred after 1980, in recognition of the government's long-standing commitment on this subject.
February 24, 1992

Another longstanding commitment that would be honoured in this legislation is the provision of an early retirement program for operational employees in the Correctional Service of Canada. I am sure most hon. members have been made aware of the need for this program by the efforts of the CSC employees. I am sure members would agree tjiat work in this field is highly stressful and that it is important that individuals who choose such a career should know that there are alternatives available to them if they cannot continue their career for as long as might normally be possible in other lines of work.
It is also important both in terms of achieving the objectives of the correctional service system and ensuring public safety that this particular labour force have such flexibility. While the detailed terms of the program are to be specified by regulation, and this would be done only after consultation with representatives of the employees concerned, I would expect that it would be similar to the voluntary early retirement provisions that are currently found in the Public Service Superannuation Act for air traffic controllers.
In essence, that program permits individuals to choose to retire at age 50 or later with 25 or more years of service and receive an unreduced pension with indexing payable from age 60. Like air traffic controllers, CFC employees covered by the program would be required, of course, to make additional contributions toward these benefits.

Another aspect of the Public Service plan and the plans of the Canadian Forces and RCMP has been criticized by plan members as imposing hardship. That is the provisions of the plans dealing with pension coverage during leave without pay. While most plan members would agree that provisions which allow pension rights to be accumulated in respect of leave without pay are a positive benefit, some find unduly onerous the requirement that the contributions owing for such periods must be repaid beginning immediately on return to duty.
Government Orders
This is especially true if the employee is required to contribute at double the rate for the period. The bill proposes that an employee be allowed to choose whether or not to count periods of leave without pay in excess of three months. At the same time it would allow an individual who initially chooses not to count the period an opportunity later to elect to reinstate the period as pensionable service. Again the bill seeks to recognize that additional flexibility for plan members is necessary to permit them to manage their personal affairs.
I might mention too that this provision, like that for coverage of part-time employees, would particularly benefit women who continue to be the employees with the greatest need for room to balance family and career commitments. Many women, for example, take advantage of extended periods of leave without pay for the purpose of caring for young children or for elders, and this provision would enhance their ability to return to work without undue financial hardship.

I would draw hon. members' attention to two other provisions affecting some members of our Canadian Forces and the RCMP.
One of these is the addition of the provision in the Canadian Forces Superannuation Act that would extend pension coverage to a full-time member of the reserve force who had previously left the regular forces without entitlement to a pension. Pension contribution would commence after one year of reserve service and the individual would be permitted to elect to count prior service in the forces of full-time reserve. Again the proposal is directed at meeting the needs of individuals to meet their own career and personal goals.
In the case of the RCMP, Bill C-55 includes provisions which would standardize the age and service requirements for voluntary retirement of officers with those for non-officers. To date, officers must have 30 years of service and be age 55 or have 35 years service to retire without a pension penalty. Non-officers may retire after 25 years of service. Clearly, this existing distinction could act as a disincentive for an RCMP member of long service to accept a commission as an officer.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
These are the major proposals of the bill which affect members of the pension plans as employees, but plan members also see these plans as a critical part of the over-all financial planning package for their unique family situation.
I would to review now some of the important proposals which affect this aspect of the plan.
Of the broadest impact would be changes to the supplementary death benefit provisions which are found in part II of the current Public Service Superannuation and Canadian Forces Superannuation Acts. This is essentially a form of life insurance for the members of these plans which provides a lump sum payment to their designated beneficiaiy or their estate upon death. The benefit is now set at a level essentially equal to annual salary although benefits decline by 10 per cent per annum from age 60. From age 65, a paid up benefit of $500 is provided and after age 70 that is the only benefit payable.
For some time now concern has been expressed by plan members and that concern is shared by the government about the growing reserves in the death benefit accounts established for those two plans. It has been concluded that action should be taken as quickly as possible to address this situation by making significant improvements in the level of benefits payable under the plans.
Accordingly, the bill provides that coverage for active employees be doubled and the paid up benefit be increased from $500 to $5,000.
I am pleased to advise that these improvements would be financed entirely from reserves in the plans and there will consequently be no increase in costs to participants or taxpayers. This change seems to be a fair way to deal with the need for action on this program while awaiting the results of further review of the over-all plan design and its inter-relationship with survivor benefits provided elsewhere under the pension plan.
[Translation\
In another area touching on the importance of pension plan coverage as a family financial planning matter, hon. members should note that this bill would also enact a new statute called the Pension Benefits Division Act.
For some years now provincial family law has been evolving on the subject of the inclusion of entitlements under employer sponsored pension plans as a part of the family assets accrued during marriage. In most jurisdictions the value of pension plan accruals is now taken into account in arriving at decisions about the division of assets on marriage breakdown. In most jurisdictions provincial pension standards legislation requires plan sponsors to recognize and act on court orders or legal separation agreements which specify a division of pension assets.
[English\
Indeed the Federal Pension Benefits Standards Act requires that employer sponsored plans subject to that act recognize such orders or agreement. The federal pension statutes, which would be amended by Bill C-55, are not currently subject to any of this legislation and at present no such request can be honoured. This has clearly led to considerable difficulty for some plan members and their spouses in settling their personal affairs since pension values can be a large part of the total family assets.
The government believes its pension plans should be able to accommodate such situations. A method to do so is set out in the proposed new pension benefits division act. This act would allow the legal or common law spouse access to up to 50 per cent of the value of the pension benefits accrued during the period specified in the court order or agreement. This would be done by having that value transferred to another retirement savings vehicle or in the case of a retirement compensation arrangement or RCA directly to the spouse.
The act, together with appropriate regulations, would provide that an offsetting reduction could then be made in the plan member's pension under the plan.

I would particularly like to draw to hon. members' attention one other proposal in Bill C-55 which would apply to all plans. Representations have been made to me and, I am sure, to other hon. members, that a change should be made to the current provisions of the pension statutes which preclude payment of a survivor's pension to a person who was not the spouse of the plan member when the member retired.
February 24, 1992

I sympathize with the desire of pensioners to ensure the financial security of those they marry after retirement. However, the government does not feel it appropriate to extend the current survivor arrangements so that an additional pension liability of this sort is automatically assumed by the plan. Nevertheless, this possibility will be considered further as part of the broader review exercise which will include study of the current survivor benefit arrangements in general.
In the meantime, and in conclusion, I am pleased to point out that Bill C-55 would allow pensioners under all of the plans who are in this situation an opportunity to provide for survivor benefits. In effect, individuals may elect to reduce their own pension in order to provide for benefits to a person whom they many after retirement. For example, for a 60-year old man who married a woman three years younger than himself, a reduction of 15 per cent in his pension would provide a widow's pension of 50 per cent in the event of his death.

In my remarks I have tried to touch on the major initiatives to be found in this bill and explain why the government feels it is necessary to move on these matters at this time.
There are, of course, other aspects of the bill of smaller impact in terms of the numbers affected. These will be discussed as we move to a more detailed consideration.
I would like to end my remarks today by reminding hon. members that Bill C-55 represents only a step in the Public Service pension reform process.
I expect to have the opportunity to bring forward broader and more fundamental legislation on this subject at a later date, if necessary. I will do so only after serious and detailed study of the issues and after consultation with all those who are affected or have an interest.

Mr. Speaker, I notice the hon. minister's comments that he wants to bring the pensions in the public sector of Canada into line with the same standards applied to other pension plans. All I can say is that it has taken an awfully long time to make one tentative step forward.
Government Orders
It is always a pleasure to get up and say when the government is doing something right. In this particular bill it is doing a few small things right.
However, the government is so unaccustomed to it, it is so tentative about it, that the best it can do is take one small step and get a little toe into the puddle of doing things the right way.
It is really quite unacceptable. Equality is an absolute term. It is not something we can give people in little bits and pieces as the mood moves us. Equality is a right.
It is appropriate in this year, 10 years after the adoption of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms that the government for the first time, with one small exception is making a step toward equality and fairness in its pension plan.
Even before the charter was applied to pension considerations an all-party parliamentary committee in 1983 made a major report proposing changes similar to or at least including those which are before the House today.
In 1985 we had the report on Equality For All that proposed exactly the same changes. That same year the government amended the Pension Benefits Standards Act that applies to all federally regulated employers to implement many of those changes to bring pension plans across Canada into conformity with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Not too long after, it made similar amendments to the Canada Pension Plan paying attention to the parliamentary committee on pension reform and paying attention to people's rights under the charter.
But it has taken a full decade before it will even take a first tentative step toward applying the charter to its own pension plans.
We see this in a number of fields. We certainly see it in employment equity where the government passes legislation that says that companies that are regulated by the federal government or do business with the federal government have to be equal opportunity employers. Until now the government has refused to bring itself under the same rules and regulations. We now have major business organizations asking that it do exactly that, that it not apply rules to others that it is not prepared to live by itself.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
We see the government talking about pay equity but refusing to implement it, and in fact fighting it through the courts. We have a constant pattern of do as I say, not do as I do.
Again this morning the minister has talked about a process for fundamental review of the pension plan. Ele knows its inadequacies perhaps better than I do. He knows the ways in which it does not conform with the same standards required of other pension plans.
The words he said this morning about consultation and a thorough review with all the stakeholders might be encouraging, except we have heard them often before from the President of Treasury Board. Since 1987 the previous President of Treasuiy Board has promised exactly the same thing, saying that Public Service employees would not have to wait long for equality, would not have to wait long for a fair rate of return on their pensions, would not have to wait long for a say in how their pension plans would be managed, among other things. Yet here we are five years later and they are still waiting.
I hope the President of Treasury Board will not blame me or a quarter of a million Public Service employees if we do not hold our breath. His announcement was made in December that this review would happen, and just this past week before the public accounts committee the person who is to be responsible for that review admitted that no, they had not talked to any of the unions yet and nothing had been done to get the process started.
We will deal with what is before us in the bill but recognize that it is a very small, tentative and inadequate step toward even conformity with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. A decade after the adoption of the charter I frankly think that is a little bit disgraceful.
I think it is also brought about by the fact that there happen to be a number of court cases under way. Even with this legislation in front of us, the government has chosen not to deal with all the issues that are in those cases in front of the Supreme Court but rather has chosen to fight equality in the courts on pension matters.
Let me deal with some of the specific issues in the bill that have been recommended, as I said over and over again, as changes to be made to this pension plan, changes which have been made and which are required of private sector companies that have pension plans but
which the government has chosen not to impose upon itself.
The minister has spoken very briefly about a change to the provisions with respect to divorce and separated spouses. One way of doing that is indeed, as this bill proposes, to allow for a division of the assets in the pension fund at the time of a separation or divorce. However, that is far from dealing with all the issues involved and it is far from meeting the standards required of other pension plans. In fact we are still left with the situation where Treasury Board has the discretion, believe it or not, to deem a spouse to be dead just because they happen to be separated and Treasury Board has decided they are not entitled to a share of pension.
The bill requires court orders. I hope the minister is seeking some expert outside advice on how that affects the equality of women and their entitlement to a fair share of family assets on divorce and marriage breakdown. Right now he has a case before the courts. He had it in his office and was able to deal with it a number of months ago and chose not to honour a court order for splitting of pension benefits. I hope he will forgive many women, who were married for 25, 30, 35 or more years while the pension was being accumulated and now have no share in that pension, a bit of skepticism about why this very narrow concession to their interest is being made and why the government is not going all the way as it has required other pension plans to do in allowing them simply a prorated share of the pension that they helped earn.
This is a complex issue and many more points need to be dealt with in conjunction with it. I certainly hope that we are going to have time at the legislative committee to do that and that there is not going to be, again, a requirement to report back in an unreasonably short period of time.
I also hope that perhaps the minister will look at splitting the equality provisions in this bill. I think it is really quite unconscionable to put equality into a bill along with a whole lot of other technical amendments that are required because of changes to the Income Tax Act and perhaps require that people who have been waiting a decade for equality will wait even longer while we go through all the implications of the Income Tax Act for other whole sections of the act that are unrelated to their needs and to their rights.
February 24, 1992

I would like to touch on a couple of other cases where the government has been much more generous with its legislated requirements for other pension plans than it is prepared to be for its own employees and their spouses, survivors and dependants.
The government knows full well that the vast majority of those elderly living in poverty are women and that one of the prime reasons for that is the lack of access to pension benefits.
Even a spouse of a pensioner who has contributed, usually through her work in the home for many years, to the accumulation of that pension now gets only 50 per cent of the pension under the Public Service plan. Yet the government, seven years ago, required private sector employers to provide 60 per cent survivor benefits.
Why does the government think that a company, whether it is running a retail store, a car dealership or a steel foundry can provide 60 per cent survivor benefits but the Government of Canada cannot?
As I said, there is a number of equality issues involved in this bill. There are a number of equality issues that should be in this bill that are not. I can only commend the minister on the provision with respect to part-time employees. As he knows full well, that applies not only largely to women but is also an important element of allowing persons with disabilities to remain involved in the work force as long as and to the extent possible and continue to receive all the benefits of being employed.
I have been speaking about the Public Service plan. Of course, as the minister has said, this bill applies also to Armed Forces and RCMP plans. Those have a number of specific provisions that are not being addressed in this bill, but again we have a promise that sometime in the future they will be addressed.
I think the minister is well aware of the concerns of Armed Forces pensioners about early retirement which is often not a matter of choice and about their pensions which for many years remain unindexed so that the pensioners drop into poverty well before their pensions start to have any degree of protection against inflation.
There are a number of other issues as well that the bill does not deal with which relate certainly to part-time
Government Orders
employees and people who are in and out of the work force more often. We know that they are more often women than men, that this is a major contributor to the poverty of women, and that has to do with how soon one is entitled to the contributions one has made to that pension plan, known as vesting.
With an economy that is changing dramatically and rapidly, the question of portability and when one is able to transfer one's pension to another employer become very important issues. These are issues that are not dealt with in this bill.
In summary, there are equality issues that are barely touched in this bill. I do believe it is unconscionable after a decade of the charter that the government would impose on other employers the obligation to be a fair employer with respect to pension matters and not take that responsibility unto itself. It is part of the cynicism that is rampant in the country right now; again the attitude of do as I say but there are special rules for me and I do not have to live by everybody else's rules.
I want to return to the next phase because the minister has promised a review. As I have said, we have had those promises repeatedly over the years. I really am not expecting a great deal, especially knowing that it was announced in December and still has not started.
The minister is aware as well that government is promoting labour-management partnerships to the tune of $1.4 million in expenditure of public funds. Yet I do not believe there has been consultation on this bill before it came forward. I am not sure that there is going to be consultation in the review process. If there is, it certainly has not started yet. In fact the minister's own summary of what is happening next says that they will take into account views expressed by others. Taking into account is not the same as consulting, and one has to ask the question: "Whose money is this anyway?"
It is interesting when we look back on the history of the Public Service Pension Plan, because every year since its inception until this year it has paid more into government coffers than it has taken out. As recently as 1989,1 believe, that amount was $400 million in excess of contributions over pay-out. Every year since the plan

Government Orders
was instituted in the mid-1950s it has contributed to reducing the tax requirements of the government and reducing the borrowing requirements of the government. The Public Service Pension Plan alone in that peak year was responsible for reducing the public deficit of Canada by $400 million.
I have spoken in this House often about the management record of the government, which I do not think is terribly good, and the pension plan again shows that. Whereas in 1989 there was that substantial surplus of contributions over payments out of the pension plan, there has been a dramatic plunge; the situation is reversed. For the first time ever the pension plan has paid out more than it has taken in. That means the government is not getting the benefit of a well managed fund which is helping to reduce the deficit but in fact is now having to pay out of public coffers toward the viability of the pension plan.
There are a number of reasons for this. The Auditor General, in last year's report, was very clear about the irresponsibility of the government in how it manages, how it reports, and how it accounts for the management of this fund. So serious are those charges that the public accounts committee has now undertaken a thorough review. The minister has not indicated in any way how his review is going to take account of those complaints of the Auditor General, but the Auditor General said: "If this were a well managed pension fund, invested as private sector pension funds are, it would be generating a far greater rate of return than it does". He criticized the lack of accountability in how the government borrows from this fund and reports to Parliament. He made it clear that Parliament has no way of holding the government accountable based on the current reporting procedures for its borrowing, all of which are debt and deficit related.
One only needs to read the Auditor General's report to realize why in a broader sense we now have double the deficit and double the debt we had when this government took office.
The minister has spoken about the interests of Canadian taxpayers. The interests of Canadian taxpayers is first and foremost in having whatever funds are in the hands of the government well managed and well reported so that people know how their money is being used, how it is being spent, how it is being lent, and so on. As well, the Auditor General had a number of things to say about management, pointing out again that the government has required all private sector employers to
have employees involved in the management of what is after all their fund, yet the government has refused repeatedly to do that. I want to point out one more thing. This bill will be in committee very shortly. Naturally we all want to see positive moves toward equality in the bill implemented as soon as possible.
I ask the minister to consider taking those provisions out of this bill, allowing them to be reported back into the House so that a somewhat shameful record of not implementing equality for public sector pensioners for a decade can at least start to be undone.
Dealing with a bill of this magnitude is also going to require understanding the economic implications for the pension fund of the measures we will be asked to approve.
I would like to point out again to the minister that I have written to him requesting copies of any studies that have been done which show the implications for the pension fund of a number of the measures contained in this bill. We have not been provided with those studies, if they have been done. I certainly hope we do not have measures before us without the ability to define what the implications are going to be. I would ask that he provide those as quickly as possible because essential and long overdue changes in this bill can be put into legislation quickly.
I urge him to be most generous when this bill is in committee, in terms of considering amendments that would move a little further along to the equality for women particularly, persons with disabilities who are affected by the provisions of this bill thought they had won 10 years ago but are still battling for in the courts.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak at second reading of this bill and to clarify that this bill deals with public sector pensions as well as those of members of Parliament that the minister spoke to earlier.
In general my party and I support the provisions of the bill. It will go to committee after second reading and we will be proposing amendments to the bill. We support those provisions related to the non-political public sector part of the bill. We will not vote against the bill at second reading because we want to get it into committee and have some of the changes that the previous speaker alluded to that are so important, as well as have a full discussion and hear witnesses from various representatives and interested parties.
February 24, 1992

New Democrats have certainly led the way in promoting strong and progressive pension plans for public sector workers. We have led the way in establishing and improving pensions for all Canadians. One among us, I believe, deserves special mention, our friend Stanley Knowles who devoted so much of his career to the cause of public pensions and a dignified retirement for all Canadians.
Public sector pensions are not what I want to speak to today. There will be ample opportunity in committee to hear witnesses and to make appropriate amendments.
I think it is long overdue that we raise the question of pensions of members of this House, pensions that at this time mean that after six years of service, members of this House receive a pension regardless of age or whether or not they move on to employment elsewhere in the federal government.
In short, I believe that the time has come to recognize that those pensions must be brought in line with the general workforce. The time has come to bring pensions for members of Parliament into line with the pensions of other Canadians. What is the rationale for the present situation?

It is partly because politicians are very aware of the precarious nature of a political career.
Most women and men who enter politics do so at great personal cost. They risk their career and at times give up a much higher salary. Very often they face an uncertain future.
One cannot know what will happen at the end of a parliamentary career, whether it is given up willingly or not. I understand that. New Democrats understand that.
In the past the transition for us NDP members was often much more difficult than it was for those from the other political parties.
We know that people who choose this life make great sacrifices. But I would like to tell you, and I say clearly,
Government Orders
that it does not justify a pension plan like the one that exists now.
We need to have a pension plan like most workers have. Nothing in all that justifies receiving a generous pension at the same time as another public sector salary.

This is a subject of great intention and differing points of view in the public and I suspect in this House. There are transition difficulties facing parliamentarians when their parliamentary careers voluntarily or involuntarily are brought to an end. I do not believe the way to deal with that is through the pension plan nor through simply assuring that people will have a pension for life after six years of service regardless of their age. There are other ways to deal with this, as it is dealt with in the public domain, and that is through a severance package which is geared to helping those who need to make that transition. It is of sufficient scope to deal with some of those prices of public life.
I do not think we can build a rationale based on the sacrifices we make. We all chose this career. We all ran for political life because we wanted to serve our country. I do not believe this makes us special. It means we have chosen this career because we believe on all sides of this House that we have something to contribute to public life. There are many Canadians who contribute to public life; many do it voluntarily. Many put themselves on the line by expressing their views publicly. There is no doubt that parliamentarians, because we fight for our beliefs and we do so publicly, are subject to closer scrutiny by prospective employers.
It is the union workers who put their views on the line and can be fired from the company. There have been examples, of course, in the public sector, where members have expressed their views and have put their future on the line. We are not alone in this.
We may have some special problems but we are not alone. In itself this is not a good enough rationale in my view. I remind members of this House there is no other Canadian in this country who receives a pension after six years.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
The autoworkers, whose plant shut down just today, certainly will not have that kind of pension. The fish plant workers who saw their jobs disappear last week will not have that kind of pension. None of these Canadians, nor the millions of others in a similar position, can count on a plan such as our own.
It is time we came to grips with this in this House. Since the last legislation was passed, there have been a variety of changes made to assist members of Parliament. Some of them should go further in making that transition.
We are accountable for the public trust. We are accountable to those who elected us to make sure that what we support is fair, not less but fair, and that each and every one of us can stand before the electorate of Canada and say that we have put in place a fair system.
I suppose if we are prepared to fight for a pension scheme such as we have for all Canadians, this side of the House would be very happy to support that.
We would be happy to support a pension plan that would be publicly managed so that people could have true portability and could have pension plans that truly serve the interests of all Canadians. But that is not what is at issue in this bill and I do not believe that we can ignore, as parliamentarians, that this bill deals with parliamentary pensions and members of Parliament pensions.
There are many things that make it more difficult for members of Parliament, but any one of us who speaks to our political staff would find that there are the same arguments, because they have chosen a political party, they have stated their views as well and they too would have a difficult time. They do not have a pension similar to what we have.
I believe that the essence of democracy is that we work for things in this House to make it more representative; things like affirmative action so we have more women in this House, we have more visible minorities and we have more aboriginal people.
I believe we work for electoral reform so that people with disabilities and people on low income can be assisted to run for this House of Commons and Parliament and participate in the parliamentary system. In that
way we will have better decisions, a better Parliament and a fairer Parliament.
I do not believe that we can simply rationalize the kind of provisions that have been made for us when we look at what is happening to Canadians across this country.
Therefore, I want to give notice that while we will be pursuing amendments in all aspects of this bill, I will be pursuing amendments relating to the age of eligibility for members of Parliament pensions so that eligibility is brought in line with the general public and private sector and amendments that would restrict a former member of Parliament from collecting an MP pension cheque while having also a federal government job, commonly known as double dipping.
Let me also suggest that I believe the bill before us should be split so that the issues of public sector pensions and those of MPs can be dealt with separately. I think this would be a fairer thing to do.
In referring to members of Parliament pensions in this bill, the minister said that the government was intending to study this. There have been a number of studies back in 1969 and I am sure many others that have been done over the years. Let me say to the minister that we have now the opportunity to take some steps into making the benefits that we have in line with those of the general Canadian public.
I also believe that the time has come to establish a non-partisan, independent commission to deal with the issues of MP pensions; not ex-members of Parliament, as has been the case before, as many of the provinces have, to look at the whole issue of members of Parliament pensions.
Having said that, I do believe that we have an opportunity to do something now that is logical, that is consistent with the public domain and that just simply is common sense.
I believe we can make changes that are fair and certainly do not require extensive study.

In 1992 when people are being asked to make one sacrifice after another, when social programs are being cut, when times are tough, members of Parliament cannot in good conscience continue to advocate for themselves a pension plan that other people can only dream of.
February 24, 1992



The time has come for us to address this directly, to address it in committee after the passing of second reading and to be no more generous than what we advocate for other Canadians. We now have an opportunity to make a step forward. We can set a new direction here. We can demonstrate to Canadians a new kind of politics vyhere fairness is our guiding principle.
I hope that the minister will be open to these issues and that they will have a fair and open debate in committee. I want to assure the minister that we want to see this bill go forward because we believe that the minister has made some positive proposals for public sector workers. I also say to the minister that now is the time to address the other pressing issue and that is of our own benefits.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great attention to the discourse of the hon. member for Yukon about double dipping. I wonder if triple dipping is equally wrong.
If an individual was a federal appointee, had been a federal MP and had been a member of the Ontario legislature and in each case for exactly the amount of time required to receive a pension, is that wrong as well? If so, has she phoned Mr. Deans to tell him about it?

Mr. Speaker, there are many exmembers of Parliament, I am sure quite legally and under the rules that exist, as well as the Senate and the bench who are following what the procedure has been.
I am not going to phone anybody. Why should I phone anybody? I am asking that every member in this House tells their electors that from now on it is not okay for MPs to have a pension that no other Canadian has. That is what I am going to do.

Mr. Speaker, the remarks of the Leader of the New Democratic Party are shared by many people in this country at this particular moment. As she has stated so often, all members of Parliament and all legislatures are held in disrepute and there is a terrible lack of trust.
Government Orders
I am trying to understand where the member is coming from. If someone served as a member of Parliament for eight or ten years and wanted to continue serving the Government of Canada in a capacity other than an elected member, and if they were to forgo that pension option but would work somewhere in the Public Service, would the hon. member consider that a fair exchange rather than taking up the pension? At least that experience and that commitment to public life could be exercised in some other part of the Public Service somewhere in the country or around the world? Would the hon. member consider that a worth-while option as a counter proposal?

Mr. Speaker, I am not suggesting that the experience that members of Parliament or indeed senators have would not be valuable in various domains of public service and paid public service. I would not suggest that at all.
All I am saying is it is not very logical to most Canadians, and quite frankly not very logical to me, that if you have a public sector job paid for by the taxpayers that you are at the same time receiving a pension. Of course, you would receive the pension upon retirement. No one is suggesting that not be the case.
Of course I think members of Parliament have much to offer to public life when they are no longer sitting members of Parliament.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have to be very clear. Is double dipping right or wrong? It was wrong a few minutes ago when it is was part of the prepared text. In answer to a question it seemed to be okay.
I want it clear. Is double dipping or triple dipping right or wrong? I think parliamentarians and Canadians have a right to know.
Perhaps the member could indicate to us as well, given her vast knowledge of this topic, whether she thinks that contributions made to the fund by MPs are in a deficit position at the present time and, if so, by how much?

Mr. Speaker, it is really interesting to me that the Liberal Party seems to want to justify that you can get both a pay cheque and a pension. I think this is great.
What I want to say is that we are making a moral judgment here. I am saying it is time to change the law and those who are currently doing that would be subject to the changed law. It is as simple as that. You get a federal government pay cheque or you get a pension.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
In terms of the pension fund, as the member well knows, the pension fund itself is not in deficit but there is a $144 million unfunded liability, but that is not the issue.
That is something we can discuss in committee and I am sure the government will have proposals. The issue is whether members of Parliament in this House are prepared to stand up and say: "It is time for a change in this plan. We want to make improvements". This is not criticizing our colleagues of any political party. My predecessor from the Yukon, I am sure, has a pension from the federal government and also has a federal government job. I do not criticize my predecessor, even though he is from the Tory Party, for doing that. What I am saying is that it is time for us to stand up and make some changes now, not simply to criticize.

Mr. Speaker, I am trying very hard to understand where the hon. member is coming from here. There are tens of thousands of people in police forces and fire departments across this country who put in their time and their years and sometimes their pensions mature when they are in their early fifties or sometimes late forties. Many of these, what I would consider to be pretty healthy pensions, tend to come from organizations that tend to be very well organized, mostly trade union operations. Is the member suggesting that the double dipping she refers to, which should not be allowed, I understand, should also apply to those public sector operations as well or is she just saying parliamentarians?

Mr. Speaker, let me make it perfectly clear. This is referring to a bill which is before us, which includes MPs' pensions. The amendments which I suggest we should make refer to MPs' pensions and this in fact is an opportunity for us to deal with those. One of those issues is a federal government pay cheque or pension or both. I am referring simply to MPs' pensions at this time.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
I have a short question for the leader. I found her speech to be most interesting and challenging.
I want to ask her this: There are a number of pension plans in Canada that are what we refer to as offside. There is the constabulary in Newfoundland, the teachers in Newfoundland and various other groups throughout Canada who have a special job, such as prison guards and so on and so forth, that have special features to their pensions. What the hon. member is referring to today are the pensions of members of Parliament to bring them in line with other pensions.
Is she suggesting at the same time that these other groups in our society who have special pension plans and abide by the law as amended should also be brought in line to conform with the status quo across Canada of the same pension for everyone?

Mr. Speaker, I realize that hon. members would like to do anything to avoid addressing the issue of MPs' pensions. I will respond to the member because he asks a good question. I am making proposals on MPs' pensions and I am suggesting, as I suggested in my remarks, that we should look at a non-partisan committee to look at all of the details of the bill, that there are certain things we could take action on now. The hon. member makes certain points about other kinds of pension plans. That is why I feel what is essential to this is that we do have a non-partisan committee, not of ex-MPs as we have done before, to study this. I am also saying, dealing with members of Parliament pensions, there are certain measures we can take now.
