speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance has promised to deliver a realistic budget tomorrow. The reality today is that 2,000 workers at GM in St. Catharines have lost their jobs. The reality today is that thousands and thousands of fishermen and fish plant workers will lose their jobs veiy soon.
February 24, 1992

Will the Minister of Finance introduce a plan that will deal with these realities tomorrow? Will the Minister of Finance introduce a plan that will get Canada working again?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the hon. Leader of the Opposition knows that the unfortunate announcement from General Motors not only covered a plant in St. Catharines but covered a number of plants in the United States and is a part of the restructuring that General Motors is undergoing. It does not make the job losses any less painless. We, of course, will do all within our power to help those people when the plant is planned to be closed by 1995.
Might I urge my friend from the Liberal Party to be patient. Tomorrow afternoon at 4.30 p.m. the Minister of Finance will deliver a budget that I am sure the Leader of the Opposition will praise and go across this country supporting the Minister of Finance in his endeavours.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, there is nothing that I would like more than to be able to get up and praise the government if it were to take care of the 1.5 million people who want the dignity of having a pay cheque. I can tell the minister if the government does that, we will praise it, but if it keeps ignoring the reality and the misery of these people, we will fight it. What is important at this moment is to make sure we get Canadians working again. Will the minister inform the Minister of Finance that yes, we will support him if he has some programs to help the unemployed. Will he please tell him as well that we will fight him if he keeps doing what the previous Minister of Finance did to this country in the last seven years?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
The previous Minister of Finance and the present Minister of Finance have been working very, very hard to get interest rates down, to get inflation down. They have accomplished both. There are 1.5 million more people working today than there were in 1984 with full time permanent jobs. A lot of very good things have happened in this country.
I am sure the hon. member will be very, very pleased when the budget comes down tomorrow to support it. I
Oral Questions
have every confidence that he will applaud the Minister of Finance tomorrow. It is obvious that he still has his adrenalin going from his convention on the weekend. I hope he will cany it over to tomorrow.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the minister. Did the minister or some of his colleagues happen to watch Radio-Canada last night when Celine Galipeau interviewed workers in the automobile industry who were 47 to 52 years old, with 25 to 27 years of experience, and who at their age were faced with losing their jobs and were not at all hopeful for the future?
Will the government finally realize that pleasing the financial community is not as important as restoring the dignity of these people who want to work and enjoy the satisfaction of earning a decent living?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: That is exactly what this government is working toward. My colleague, the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, together with his colleague, the Minister of Employment and Immigration, are working very, very hard on a prosperity program which in fact stresses training and retraining and the encouragement of industries to train and retrain. Our record in Canada is not one that we can be proud of in that area. That is what they are working on at this time, to assure that people have full-time, meaningful jobs, not just make-work programs, throwing money at problems like the Liberals would have us do.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
The government is about to approve the demise of the cod fisheries. The government says it is powerless, but it is time it realized that it does have the tools to do something. The environment is one.

February 24, 1992
Oral Questions
My question is this: Will the minister promise to immediately ratify the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea? Second, will she reverse the defeatist attitude she took on the weekend and take a proactive stance at the earth summit in Brazil? Third, will she protect the entire environment of the Grand Banks, including fisheries resources? Will she act unilaterally and do so immediately?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
The hon. member is asking two separate questions. One comes out of my statements on Friday, that of the great significance of the UNCED meeting in June in Rio for a variety of purposes, in which Canada is taking a leading role. I think it is important to understand that we see this as one step and not the step in protecting our environment. Therefore we do not want to see expectations raised too high. We want to deal in realities.
On the second point I should say we are working very hard through the preparatory committee that will take place in New York very shortly on ensuring that fisheries and marine conservation are very much a part of that UNCED agenda.

Mr. Speaker, it may be that I asked two separate questions. It would have been very helpful if the minister had answered at least one of them.
For three years, this government has stood on the sidelines and watched this country absorb blow after blow. Now it is the turn of the fishing industry and it is not true that Canada is helpless. The fact is that it is this government that is hopeless.
Two years ago the Oceans Institute of Canada at Dalhousie University stated that the environmental need to conserve fish stocks inside the 200-mile limit gave the government the right in international law to go beyond the 200-mile limit to prevent overfishing. Why has the government not exercised that right?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a list of seven or eight things that the government is doing with regard to overfishing. No one takes this more seriously than we do.
First of all, I should point out that we will be informing through our embassies in the EC and the NAFO countries this serious scientific evidence that has come to us in the last week. The Minister of Fisheries and I will be meeting with the EC ambassadors later this week. It is important to make the Europeans understand that this is not just a domestic fisheries issue. The information that we have puts the whole North Atlantic fishery at some sort of risk. Therefore it is in their own self-interest.
We are also pursuing the inclusion of this in the UNCED conference in June. Indeed, if at the end of all our diplomatic efforts we are not able to have an impact, we will have to consider further steps, and we are prepared to do that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister. It concerns the announcement today about the thousands of workers in Atlantic Canada who will be affected once again and will quite possibly lose their jobs.
The government has known for years that this was going to happen. There have been studies. Yet the government's response to these people in Atlantic Canada is that a task force will be established to look at the impact. The impact is clear. The impact is that these people will have no jobs. I want to ask the government why this total disregard for the Atlantic fisheries? Why so late to do anything? Not only does it show mismanagement, it shows callousness to the people of the Atlantic region. When is this government going to make unemployment a priority and start planning to make sure that Canadians can get back working?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is asking what actions can and will be taken for Atlantic Canadians who live off our fisheries.
What the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans announced this morning was a very sensitive conservation and management program of the resource to ensure that this resource is there in the future to allow the people who live off that resource to be able to earn a living. In the meantime, we have a series of programs trying to help these people adjust to those changes in the fishery. If the hon. member says that nothing is being done, she should
February 24, 1992

look at the details of the $584 million program we announced two years ago.

Mr. Speaker, it is clear that the government has failed to plan for the plight of the people in the Atlantic region that is happening now. It knew this was coming. There is no real plan in place.
While the government says that the war on inflation is over, it is time to take care of the casualties of that war, the 1.5 million unemployed, those people on social assistance, those people who are losing hope. Today, the Conference Board of Canada said that if the government continues with its policies, the recovery will be further hindered. I want to ask the Acting Prime Minister if he agrees that what this country needs is a budget based on a policy of zero unemployment. Is this government going to bring forward such a policy in the budget tomorrow?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, of course unemployment is of great concern to the government and that will be addressed in the budget tomorrow.

Mr. Speaker, I certainly hope that it is addressed more specifically than it was in the Atlantic when this government knew that there was a situation of crisis there.

It is high time this government started being as energetic about creating jobs as it was about fighting inflation. On behalf of all unemployed Canadians, will the Deputy Prime Minister start concentrating all his energy and resources on getting rid of policies that have put 1.5 million people out of work and hundreds of thousands of Canadians on welfare while also causing many bankruptcies?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can tell the hon. member, first of all for her edification, that Canada is not the only country that has gone through a recessionary period. It has happened around the world, but I can tell the hon. member that because of the policies of this government
Oral Questions
Canada is much better poised to come out of the recession than any other country in the G-7.
As a matter of fact, all the prognosticators, those outside our government, are being far more small l liberal in their projections of what will happen in the next couple of years than the government. I think that the policies of the government of the past seven or eight years have allowed us to come out of this recession leading in the modem world, in the OECD and in the G-7. I think the hon. member will be pleased with the budget tomorrow of the Minister of Finance.

Mr. Speaker, General Motors has just announced a further 2,300 job lay-offs in Canada's industrial heartland. Since the government has had at least two months notice of GM job cuts, would the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology inform the House today of his specific plans for ensuring that these workers have jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend is well aware that we have had a general indication from the people at General Motors that in North America they would be making some significant reductions in employment. Where those were going to occur we could not tell until the actual announcements had been made.
Some announcements were made this morning. They are very troublesome. The loss of jobs, some 2,300 jobs in St. Catharines, is very bad news as far as the Niagara peninsula is concerned. We, with my colleague the Minister of Employment and Immigration, will be working with these people. I am sure my friend is aware that the lay-offs will occur over a period of time from this fall until the spring of 1995.
A large amount of the reduction will be through attrition so it is still not clear at this point how much the programs of the government will be called upon.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians do not need more studies. They do not need more delays. Canadians need jobs.
I put it to the minister that it is within his power to act to save Canadian auto jobs. It was his free trade deal that gutted the safeguards of the auto pact, and as a conse-

February 24, 1992
Oral Questions
quence Canadians are losing automotive jobs at two and a half times the rate of Americans.
Will the minister finally insist on safeguards for Canadian automotive jobs? Will he tell his trade negotiators to act today to preserve Canada's automotive industry?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not have to do that today. I have already done that.
My hon. friend should be honest with Canadian people and understand and indicate to Canadians that the free trade agreement has had nothing to do with the decision that was taken by General Motors today.
The decision has everything to do with the weakness of the automotive industry in North America. The General Motors company is way above the auto pact safeguards, and he knows that those safeguard levels were not affected at all in the free trade agreement.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade.
In his first answer to my colleague, the member for Willowdale, he said that the workers at GM and around the country in effect should not worry because the jobs would go, as he put it, by attrition.
Why does the minister not realize that you do not build an economy by attrition? Why does he not realize that Canadians do not want attrition? They want jobs.

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the only point I am making which my hon. friend is trying to distort here is that the General Motors people have said that to the extent people retire in the ordinary course or change jobs through the ordinary course that will reduce the number of lay-offs and reduce the 2,300 down to a number which is a good deal lower. That was the point I was making.
As far as the importance of jobs is concerned, my colleague the Minister of State for Finance has commented very powerfully on that in his answers earlier today. This government is very concerned about the level of employment in the country. He has indicated that the Minister of Finance is very well aware of the concerns that have been expressed, both by members of this
House as well as by Canadians in all parts of the country, and will be dealing with that in his budget tomorrow.

Mr. Speaker, the 2,300 workers at the plants at St. Catharines operated by GM that will close and Canadian workers generally will be very disappointed that the minister of industry does not have any contingency plan to announce today or any plan that could be announced in the near future for replacing the jobs that will be lost at those plants in St. Catharines.
On February 11 the minister admitted in this House that the auto pact is on the table as part of the current negotiations with the United States and Mexico. If and when these plants in St. Catharines close, what will the government be able to do to ensure that General Motors continues to meet the requirements of the auto pact for Canadian content and Canadian assembly?
Can he give us a clear answer on that key point today?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I think if my hon. friend read what I said in the House, as he said on February 11, he would know that what I said was that if there was going to be a replacement for the auto pact it would only be by something that is better.

Mr. Speaker, my question for the Secretary of State for External Affairs follows up on her meeting today with Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas.
In view of the recent report by Amnesty International which condemned the government's inquiiy into the brutal murders at Dili as being a whitewash or fatally flawed, and in view of ongoing repression including charges of students with subversion, will the minister assure this House that she supports the call for an independent, international inquiry into the Santa Cruz massacre and will Canada strongly support the European community resolution on East Timor which is currently before the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all we do not necessarily agree with the Amnesty assessment of what the Indonesian government is prepared to do as a result of the commitments made by its inquiry.
February 24, 1992

I should say that in my meeting today I expressed Canada's views again very strongly regarding the situation in East Timor. I should say as well that we are the only country in the world that is still continuing to hold back on funding new aid projects. No one else is doing that. Therefore the actions we have taken have gone well beyond the UN charter and our commitments under other international treaties.
I am really quite hopeful that the Government of Indonesia takes its responsibilities in this connection very seriously. We recognize that there is still progress that must be made and I pointed that out in the 90-minute meeting on this topic with Mr. Alatas. We will continue to monitor the situation, and if the Government of Indonesia lives up to its commitments then we will review our stand.

Mr. Speaker, the minister, of course, did not answer the question with respect to the resolution in Geneva.
I want to ask a supplementary question on another very important international human rights issue concerning the continuing imprisonment of two young Canadians in Brazil, Christine Lamont and David Spencer, sentenced to 28 years in jail.
Given the recent commitment by the Brazilian minister of justice to Christine's parents to release Christine and David if Canada formally requests their expulsion, when will the minister finally act on behalf of these two young Canadians who have been victims of a very grave miscarriage of justice and make a formal request to the Government of Brazil for their expulsion so they can return home to Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, these two young people who are in their late twenties and early thirties were found guilty in Brazil of three veiy serious charges: kidnapping, resisting arrest and conspiracy. We have examined this situation very closely, and indeed the transcripts of the trial following the appeal process are being gone over right now by our legal people. When that review is over then I will make a decision as to what action I should take.
Oral Questions
As I have indicated in this House I do think the 28-year sentence is excessive, but we do regard the kidnapping conviction as a serious one as well, as we would in our own country.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
The minister of fisheries said in St. John's this morning that the government might have to contemplate unilateral measures to stop foreign overfishing. Her colleague, the employment minister, said here in the House on Friday that the government would never do that.
I want to ask her: Which it is? Is it what the employment minister says here when the Prime Minister is listening, or is it the line being peddled today in St. John's by her colleague, the minister of fisheries, when he hopes that nobody else is listening? Which is it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have already outlined in the House today some of the steps that we are taking and are continuing to take with regard to the situation.
It has been an extraordinarily frustrating exercise to try to convince the Europeans how serious this is. We are going to take the most recent evidence to them, as I said earlier in response to a very similar question, and try to explain to them that this is in their interests as well as our own.
I also said earlier in the House today, if the hon. member was listening, that I am quite prepared to contemplate further steps should that be required as long as it is within the bounds of our capacity to act meaningfully.
Negotiations are still the best way to accomplish this, and we will contemplate future steps at the appropriate time should need arise.

It is all right, Mr. Speaker, Mighty Casey is here now. I have a supplementary question for my friend, the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, fresh from his triumphs in Newfoundland.

February 24, 1992
Oral Questions
He will know that in 1970 this Parliament, through legislation sponsored by a Liberal administration, unilaterally established functional jurisdiction over a 100-mile zone in the Canadian Arctic waters.
There is a clear precedent for what we have been advocating. Why then, I ask the minister, is the government so painfully reluctant to take unilateral action in the present case? Is it fearful of the outcome, or is it that it just does not have the heart for the fight?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wonder where the hon. gentleman was in 1972 when the treaty was entered into with France or a few years later when a treaty was entered into with members of the European community which gave them the right to fish in the same waters that the hon. gentleman says we should take unilateral action on. The hon. gentleman's government gave them the right to fish for six or seven years in these same waters.
With respect to unilateral action, we have taken dozens of unilateral actions and we are having some success. As my hon. colleague may have mentioned, the South Korean ambassador has already conveyed the message that his government has given orders for their vessels to be withdrawn from this area.
Our ambassador had a very successful series of meetings at Panama, and the Panamanian government which has a number of vessels fishing in this area owned by Spain and Portugal will also be taking steps to see to the same.
We are taking effective action unilaterally already.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
Today's announcement on the reduced northern cod quotas means in effect a reduction in jobs, lay-offs, reduced plant operations, and for many people it means no income at all. The announcement on the compensation was very general. It talked about past programs and present programs but nothing specific.
I want to ask the government and the minister of fisheries in particular, because he must know what is happening over there, to put a human face on this and
tell this House what specific compensation measures will be taken for those Atlantic Canadians involved.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I have already made clear today, when we have established exactly what the consequences of this decision are, if there is need for any additional assistance programs it will be forthcoming.
We already have in place a whole series of programs, including the first line of defence, which is the unemployment insurance program, that will apply particularly to workers in offshore plants.
We also have in place a Fisheries Alternatives Program, a Plant Workers Adjustment Program and diversification within the fisheries program. All of these programs will still apply.
When we know later in the year exactly what the effects are, other programs, if necessary, will be put into place.

Mr. Speaker, I feel sorry for the people who are watching the answer to this question. It simply is not good enough.
The government has known that this has been coming for some time. It talks about task force reports and a new task force being set up.
The people watching the answers to these questions cannot eat task force reports. They have enough in front of them now. These people, because of last year's dismal fishery, are living in an atmosphere of fear, anxiety and to a certain extent, hope. All this is compounded and aggravated by the situation today.
I am going to ask the minister one more time. He must have some idea. Let us know how much, what kind, and when.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. gentleman may want to alarm people. I do not know.
I think the hon. gentleman should be concerned about being accurate in his assessment of the situation in Newfoundland. The Newfoundland economy is not finished. This is a serious matter affecting the northern cod species.
February 24, 1992

If we just take Newfoundland alone, 61 per cent of our fishery is groundfish and 40.5 per cent is the northern cod. We still have many other species of fisheries.
The northern cod is not finished. We only caught
127,000	tonnes of the northern cod last year. The TAC just established is 120,000 tonnes. If we are lucky we may catch that this year.
If we look at Atlantic Canada, Atlantic Canada is not finished. The northern cod is 11.8 per cent of the landed value of all fisheries products in Atlantic Canada.
The region is not finished. There is no need to exaggerate. This process started several years ago. We are responding. There are programs and the economy of Newfoundland is still going to have growth this year.
If the investors listen to the doom and gloom from the opposition, Newfoundland is finished. I say there is still a lot of life in Newfoundland.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Communications. This was a question that I wanted to ask last week. Last Monday was Heritage Day but the minister was ill. I am glad to see him back in the House in good shape today.
National Heritage Day was a time to be reminded of the commitments which were forthcoming from his predecessors both in communications and environment at the Edmonton conference on heritage in 1990 where a commitment was made to a formal review toward the creation of a national heritage strategy.
My questions are obvious. Are new initiatives going to be forthcoming for a Canadian national heritage strategy? Will the public be consulted in the process? When will the discussion paper be available?

Mr. Speaker, first of all let me thank my colleague for his good wishes and I am delighted to be able to respond to his question.
Yes, we have given a very high priority to the whole field of heritage. We are working closely with my colleague, the Minister of the Environment, to prepare material with regard to this.
Oral Questions
We will be seeking public input with regard to it and we hope to take initiatives which will help to encourage and to preserve Canadian heritage.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology who said that the lay-off of 2,500 workers at GM in St. Catharines was troublesome. Probably he will find the next round of lay-offs at GM downright irritating but the workers find it catastrophic.
My question to the minister is: When is he going to act to ensure that we have free trade with Japan and the offshore automobile companies, rather than seeing the North American industry savaged as a result of this government's policies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I know that the hon. member would like to cut off all trade from Japan and all trade from other parts of the world. What we have to realize is that we have an open economy here. If we are going to start erecting barriers against trade with other countries then we are going to suffer as well from the trade that we want to do with those other countries. That is something that my hon. friend does not take into account when he asks that sort of question.

Mr. Speaker, the Japanese ship 2.5 million cars to North America a year, 25,000 North American cars are sold in Japan a year, and 2,500 Canadian workers lost their jobs. This was predictable. The government was warned of it. There is overcapacity.
Why is it too much to ask of the offshore producers that they produce jobs as well as cars in this country when they are making money?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the difficulties that we are having with the automobile industry are not just difficulties in Canada. There are difficulties in the whole North American market.

February 24, 1992
Oral Questions
The cause of the lay-offs in St. Catharines is related to difficulties more in the United States than in the market in Canada.
My hon. friend, who has put in a lot of good rhetoric out there, is not hitting the mark with what he is trying to say.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and it involves the newspaper business.
There are concerns within the industry that TorStar may be poised to gain effective control of Southam. If that happens, 47 per cent of all the English language newspapers would be concentrated in the hands of one corporation.
Does this prospect concern the minister and would his officials like to try to get the real story here?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we know that The Toronto Star has shares in Southam and Southam has shares in the other. The director of competition is fully aware of that.
If there is any possibility of a merger between the two, the director of competition has the ability to intervene. We have a competition policy, we have competition legislation and we have the competition tribunal.
The director of competition will follow that issue very closely.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
I believe all members of the House in fact all Canadians watch daily with dismay the rising tide of fascism and authoritarianism in Russia and the other republics
and the threat it poses for democracy there. Yet western countries seem paralysed to do anything.
In fact, The New York Times yesterday revealed that the United States government has refused to honour its commitment of increased obligations to the International Monetary Fund for an aid package.
In light of this deteriorating situation, I want to ask the minister: Can she indicate what plans the Government of Canada has to respond to this dangerous situation?
In particular, will the Government of Canada request a special emergency meeting of the G-7 of the IMF so we can come to grips before these forces threaten the entire economic and world security that we now face and that these represent?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the events on the weekend were indeed alarming for those of us who watched them. We have asked for a full report on exactly what the situation was in Russia on the weekend.
Let me say that in terms of aid Canada has been very active in our own right as well as multilaterally. Our aid, which is actually mostly delivered, amounts to about 40 per cent of what the Americans have pledged.
We are urging the Americans to continue to provide aid. In addition, we have called for Russia and the other republics to become members of the IMF.
We have asked for a doubling of the capital of EBRD. We are continuing to work very actively through the G-7 and our other organizations and with the European Community to try and ensure that there is sufficient aid, not just in Russia but in the other republics as well, to prevent any real tragedy.

Mr. Speaker, as a supplementary to the minister, let me ask this question.
One of the most immediate threats facing these republics is the tens of thousands of Soviet military officers and personnel who must be reintegrated and retrained and be given proper housing before they become so disgruntled that they join these authoritarian forces.
February 24, 1992

I ask the minister: Can she tell us if the Canadian government has any specific plan to help in this retraining and this re-integration of these tens of thousands of military personnel?
Will the Government of Canada commit to putting a plan together and take it to the G-7 so we can finally get some action from these countries before it turns into a total disaster?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Derek Burney, who was our Sherpa at the G-7 has been actively working with other Sherpas in order to ensure that there is a co-ordinated effort and a positive effort with regard to the former Soviet republics.
One of the things we have done with regard to the armed forces in particular is to provide a training seminar in Canada on how an army functions in a democratic society.
Senior officers from the republics were here several weeks ago meeting with our own military people in terms of the function of the army in this different environment.
The other thing is that out of the co-ordinating conference in Washington, where we were trying to ensure that countries co-ordinated and did not overlap their efforts, considerable effort is being made towards housing these people by the Germans, for example.
We believe our efforts are best directed in other areas to make sure that we are not all tripping over each other doing the same thing.

Mr. Speaker, I want to ask the Acting Minister of Finance a question.
In 1990 this government cut social housing spending by 15 per cent. In 1991 it extended those cuts until 1996. This has cost needy Canadians some 6,000 housing units so far.
Affordable housing is a fundamental part of Canada's social safety net. Yet this government has failed over one million Canadians who are still living in core need housing and thousands more who are homeless.
Oral Questions
I want to ask the minister: Will the government restore the desperately needed funds for affordable housing?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the budget will be delivered tomorrow afternoon at 4.30. I would suggest that my hon. friend have patience for another 25.5 hours until the Minister of Finance delivers that budget.

Mr. Speaker, in Quebec, 360,000 units and households are eligible for these funds, and there is a demand right now for 5,000 units. During the past five years there has been a 20 per cent cut in the federal budget for this kind of housing. The amount of money available for new projects has been going down steadily, while the demand keeps increasing.
Is the government prepared to act responsibly as a partner and provide Quebec with enough funding for social housing?

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the record will show that the federal government has been most generous with its social housing benefits, as much as our fiscal framework will allow. I think we have been very generous.
If the hon. member waits until tomorrow, she will see what news is in the budget for the housing sector.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Agriculture.
With respect to article XI and despite certain statements that were made during your trip to Europe with the hon. member for Champlain and Quebec Minister Yvon Picotte; did the European Community officially finalize its position on the review of agricultural issues in connection with GATT?

February 24, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, our trip last week was an opportunity to meet the Europeans, especially for Canada's farm leaders who travelled with the Canadian delegation.
We had a chance to meet Mr. McSharry, the agricultural commissioner, and Mr. Andriessen, the community's vice-president. Of course we did not expect to come back with article XI, safe and sound. Our main purpose was to make the Europeans aware of certain common interests.
We were given a fairly favourable reception, and talks will continue in the weeks to come. I hope that as in the past we will be able to continue to defend Canada's position and represent the interests of Canadian producers. Our trip was productive but we must keep working very hard with the delegations.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Communications.
The book publisher, Grolier Limited, has consistently and deliberately snubbed its nose in disregard to the government's Baie Comeau policy on book publishing. Last year it moved its direct mail division to the United States with a loss of over 100 jobs. Now it plans to close the school and library division, leaving nothing but a shell company in Canada. What specific measures is the minister taking to stop Groliers and other book publishers from leaving the country?

The hon. member will be aware of the fact that I announced a program just a few weeks ago which was designed to do precisely that, to ensure the health of the Canadian-owned sector in Canada. We are pumping a further $102 million into the Canadian book publishing industry. We are taking measures which will make it more profitable for firms to be owned by Canadians, to operate here and to publish Canadian titles. In this way, we hope to increase the consumption of Canadian books
and to ensure that more Canadian authors are read in this country.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is almost a supplement to the earlier question, but it is to the Minister for International Trade regarding his trip. Just to show how serious the discussions were and to try to alleviate the concern that it was just an unfortunate public relations exercise coming late in the day, did the minister discuss with officials in his meetings in New York the letter that 62 senators of the United States have written to President Bush to say that there shall be no change to the American agricultural adjustment agreement, section 22, which in effect protects cotton, dairy, peanuts and sugar under a form of supply management? Also, did he discuss that with the officials in New York, saying "hey, we have the same situation", to show how firm he is going to be in this government to help justify the concern and the good little message that the Minister of Finance made to those 30,000 farmers on Friday, that if the Americans are able to protect section 22 in their situation and we do not get clarification of article XI we are not going to go ahead and sign this deal?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend is well aware that the Americans are prepared to put section 22 on the negotiating table. That matter has not yet been resolved. It has not yet been resolved whether or not the Europeans and others will accept our position on article XI.
As my colleague said, we had good meetings last week with representatives of the farm community from coast to coast and with Mr. Yvon Picotte, Minister of Agriculture for Quebec. We met with representatives of the commission, of GATT, with the German government, and I think we made some progress. We certainly do not have a complete resolution of this issue by any means, but this was a good trip in that we advanced, I believe, our interests in a respectable way. I believe with the continuing work we can continue to make progress. We need to have the full support of this Parliament and the farmers throughout the country in order to continue to put the strongest possible position forward.
February 24, 1992
I wish to draw to the members' attention the presence in the gallery of the Hon. Roy Brassard, Minister responsible for Seniors, Government of Alberta.
Hear, hear.

subsubtopic: ENERGY, MINES AND RESOURCES FIRST REPORT OF STANDING COMMITTEE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present, in both official languages, the first report of the Standing Committee on Energy, Mines and Resources.
In June our government and many other governments will attempt to respond to concerns about global climate change at the UN Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil. They may do so by negotiating a convention to limit greenhouse gas emissions. This unanimous report of your committee on energy, mines and resources recommends that our government adopt a flexible policy that includes its stated goal of stabilizing emissions not controlled by the Montreal protocol at 1990 levels by the year 2000, and that it seek a global commitment to a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005.
Global warming is a global problem requiring global solutions and global accounting. We are, therefore, also recommending that our government support proposals that would facilitate Canada taking global action to meet its commitments.
The committee requests that the government table a comprehensive response to this report within 150 days of this date.

Mr. Speaker, it is my honour to present, in both official languages, the eighth report of the Standing Committee on Finance which completed its study in relation to the mandate and governance of the Bank of Canada.
I might say in presenting this report that, having served as chairman of the subcommittee which prepared the report, all members of the subcommittee from all of the parties worked in a very diligent and non-partisan fashion in preparing what I think is an excellent report.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. McKnight that Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to the Standing Committee on Agriculture.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: At the suspension of the debate the hon. member for Winnipeg-St. James had the floor to answer some questions.

Mr. Speaker, this will not take long. I was answering a question from my colleague for Parkdale-High Park who was pointing out that in the state of Bavaria in Germany farms are being subsidized as tourist attractions. It simply underlines the fact that countries will find one way or another of subsidizing their agricultural producers.
I want to add something to that and it has to do with the family farm. If we lose supply management, if we lose our marketing boards, I think it will result in a major loss of the family farm. It will accentuate and further push the trend toward larger and larger corporate farms.
Travelling through western Canada now and seeing some very well kept family farms is something to behold and something to look forward to. If we lose our supply management system, if we lose marketing boards, we will see fewer and fewer of those lovely family farms. It is not only in my opinion bad agricultural practice to lose family farms but we will lose some of the aesthetic beauty as well.

Mr. Speaker, it is with somewhat mixed feelings that I rise today to speak to Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act.
I work with and talk frequently to the cattle producers in my area and throughout Saskatchewan, most of whom encouraged me to support legislation which they told me would provide the cattle industry with a check-off to help market its product in Canada.
February 24, 1992

Among those supporters of the beef check-off were Lynn Biggart from Cut Knife, Saskatchewan, an active lobbyist and participant for and in the Canadian Cattlemen's Association; John Feige from Parkside, Saskatchewan, president of the Saskatchewan Stock Growers' Association; and Grant Cadieu from Spiritwood, Saskatchewan, son of the late Bert Cadieu, a former member of this House and a long time and tireless worker on behalf of Canadian Hereford breeders. All three individuals are qualified, respectable spokespeo-ple for their industry. When they talk to me I know they represent many other producers in whatever they have to say.
I have therefore been aware for some time that there was a cattlemen's lobby under way to secure funds or to help secure funds to help this industry deal with some of its most pressing problems, in particular the fight against low cost, highly subsidized European beef being dumped into the Canadian marketplace.
The idea for a check-off for cattle is one that was presented to me in a very positive way, a way that reflected a very real need within the cattle industry. I was receptive of the idea for a number of other reasons as well.
Earlier this year I attended the Northwest Hereford Club's annual meeting and I heard about the positive steps taken by people involved in the marketing of Hereford beef in Canada. I was impressed and therefore I thought that if the beef industry could take the ideas the Hereford breeders were incorporating into their work further then all producers in the beef industry could benefit.
I have already been impressed by the marketing ideas and promotions mounted by the supply managed sector. You know what I mean, Mr. Speaker, because you have seen the television commercials of egg producers, the let's get crackin commercials. Dairy people have the milk, it does a body good promotion. There are the recent butter commercials with the asparagus and the carrots dancing around on the television screen. These are great promotions. They have served their industries well and are helping to promote and produce good quality nutritional ideas among the Canadian public, certainly ideas that we all have to take to heart. They are also ideas that help us enjoy the fruits of the labour of Canada's farmers.
Government Orders
Third, I was receptive to the idea of check-offs. I am already knowledgeable of and supportive of the checkoff system in the work place where wage earners have a small portion of their regular salary deducted and used in their collective interest during the bargaining process. In the work place this is called the Rand formula and it recognizes the fact that all employees in a specific work place benefit from the collective bargaining efforts of those who were elected to do the bargaining on their behalf. Therefore, because all members benefit, all members of that bargaining unit must pay toward the achievement of that success.
The cattle check-off, therefore, seemed to me to be just an extension of the Rand formula into the cattle industry. Everyone pays for the benefit of everyone else.
I was about to congratulate my friends in the beef industry for recognizing the positive and long-lasting benefits of co-operation and socialism in their industry until I received a copy of Bill C-54 and had a chance to read and analyse it, I realized that I was not entirely correct. This is not the legislation I was expecting. The legislation is not exactly as it had been described by my friends in the cattle industry. It is not the legislation I had thought I could support without question or concern. It is really nothing more than this government's attempt to tax the individual producer one more time, provide producers' money to projects over which after they have produced it they relinquish all control and influence over the funds that are expended on their behalf.
Not only do I see this as just another tax bill, but it is also a bill which denies accountability for the money raised.
While Bill C-54 will give my friends in the cattle industry a check-off, I do not think I can support the bill as it stands. I hope they will continue to pressure the government for amendments to this bill at the committee stage, or in fact to write new legislation that will give them exactly what they do want, which is an opportunity to participate in the marketing of their product.
There is no question in my mind that the act before us requires more study, because I am not confident that it can stand up to the scrutiny of the many producers out there who want to see the product they grow and sell for their livelihoods promoted and sales increased as a result of that promotion.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
It is possible that Bill C-54 will just end up being viewed by the producers as something with the same efficiency and effectiveness as the government's introduced and implemented GST. It amounts to nothing less than another tax, something that reduces the value of their product at the point of sale.
Our goal in this House, and let us make no mistake about it, is to ensure that funds taken at the farm gate translate into higher prices for the producer. Our task is to find the proper tools to achieve that goal.
According to the information provided by the minister prior to the drafting of this legislation, the commodity groups who are pushing for check-off legislation said they wanted check-offs that were commodity based, producer or membership controlled and accountable. This bill does not go that far, extending accountability only through the start up phase.
A majority of commodity based producers must agree to set up the agency in question, but then the membership of the board can be appointed by the minister.
The commodity group membership may never have to be asked for their input again in the process of the operations of the agency.
I realize that organizations that operate with a democratic structure will remain somewhat or totally accountable for these agencies. There are other organizations out there that are not all that democratic, and that makes this legislation unfair to the producers within those commodity groups.
Check-offs are seen as an effective means of promoting self-reliance and shared responsibilities. I agree with that entirely.
The minister knows how well the supply managed commodities have done in this regard. My colleague, the member for Mackenzie, outlined this quite clearly in his intervention in this House last Wednesday when the bill was first debated.
This is a time of economic difficulty in rural Canada. Mr. Speaker, I do not have to tell you or anyone else in this House, or anyone else in Canada for that matter,
that this is a time of difficulty in rural Canada. It is an all too obvious fact.
The fact that there were some 25,000 or, depending on which media you listen to, 40,000 farm people on the Hill last week protesting and demonstrating in support of the supply managed sector in this country indicates how serious the economic difficulties in rural Canada are at the moment.
During times of economic difficulty people in rural areas pull together. They co-operate to help each other out. Our history provides many examples to illustrate exactly what I am saying. That co-operation was evident on the Hill on Friday when the producers demonstrated their support for supply management.
To see the cattle producers and other agricultural commodity groups pulling together at this time to try to improve their economic well-being is only natural. I wish them well, and I hope that they will do as well in the future as some of them have done in the past.
Therefore, I support the amendment before us which would send the bill to the agriculture committee for further study.
The concept of a check-off for the cattle producers and others is a good one. It is an idea, a concept that requires further reflection, analysis and understanding to ensure that the final bill which we approve in this House will serve the interests of the cattle producers and the community in which they live, not just the interests of the industry group they are involved in.
These are valuable and worth-while goals to be achieved. Just as I respect the work of my friends in the cattle industry, I also respect the work of my colleagues on the agriculture committee. I trust that they will do the right thing when Bill C-54 comes their way.
Mr. Speaker, I thank you for the opportunity to say a few words here today on this important act. I will save further comments for the committee stage and the third reading debate of this bill after it has had the study that I know it will get in committee.

Mr. Speaker, I could relate very well to the hon. member's comments about how serious the economic situation is in rural Canada.
February 24, 1992

It is serious when one spouse has to work at another profession, whether teaching or nursing, to supplement the farm income, or when the equipment, such as a tractor, that used to cost $40,000 now costs $150,000. I honestly do not know how these farmers are making ends meet.
Since he is very knowledgeable about the crisis in the rural parts of Canada, I would like to ask the member what recommendations he would make to help alleviate this crisis if he were in government and if he were a minister of agriculture.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to thank the member for his question. I feel quite flattered that the member would consider my views to be worthy of an agriculture minister in this country. I feel very confident that in the next government I will perhaps be given the chance to ask my leader for the opportunity to serve this country in that or any other position on the front bench opposite.
I agree with and recognize the stress apparent in the farm community emphasized by my colleague and the hon. member. The circumstances in the rural community are primarily agriculture based, but they go beyond that.
As the stability of agriculture has been eroded so too has the infrastructure of the rural communities of Canada. The school systems, the health systems, and the business community in the rural parts of Canada have diminished considerably because the stable economic structure of agriculture is not there to support it.
I have seen all too often in my own province communities disappear. That situation began because fewer and fewer farmers were working in the vicinity of a community. As the farmers moved off the land the numbers of people who attended the local church and the local school and were available to purchase goods in the local stores or utilize the facilities of the local recreational centre, skating rink and community hall decreased. This created a situation in which all of a sudden that community ceased to have viability.
When we talk about the policies and the programs that we need to put in place we must first examine the viability of agriculture, we must look at securing an economic base for agriculture so that we can maintain the populations on the farms to ensure that we have people in the vicinity of rural communities to support the activities and the structure in the rural communities.
Government Orders
First and foremost we must have policies in place that will provide for that economic stability in agriculture; that means a good price for farm products, whether beef cattle, hogs, grains, oilseeds or the cereal crops that are grown on the prairies.
We also need programs to address the needs of the rural community itself to which people from the farms have often gone to retire. We need programs that deal with housing and other issues.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling me that my time is up. I hope that over the course of the next year many of the ideas that I and the members of my party are actively engaged in examining to address the needs of rural Canada and the election platforms that are put forward will prove to the Canadian people that New Democrats have a different and more positive way of viewing the changes required to secure economic and social stability in rural Canada, and that Canadians will give us the opportunity to put those ideas into practice when the time comes.

Mr. Speaker, perhaps today we should be looking at the original legislation brought in 20 years ago, proclaimed in the other place in this Parliament in early 1972. That legislation was the basis upon which our national marketing agencies were built. Agencies that were built on the foundation of the legislation passed in this House are now on the verge of being destroyed in secret negotiations behind closed doors at the GATT with no real input from this House.
This legislation was unique in its nature because in the British North America Act the various areas of jurisdiction within this country were laid out. For example, marketing within a province was a provincial jurisdiction. We refer to that as intra-provincial trade. When a product crossed a provincial boundary or was exported it came under federal jurisdiction. We refer to that as inter-provincial trade and export trade.
In addition to export trade, which is federal jurisdiction, the powers of the federal government were melded with that of the provincial governments in terms of marketing legislation. In turn, the provincial legislation had to call upon another piece of federal legislation, the Agricultural Products Marketing Act, to get more of the powers they needed to operate effectively.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
This was Confederation working at its finest. When we had federal legislation looking after the trade within Canada between provinces federal-provincial agreements were developed and signed by all provincial ministers of agriculture in this nation to work together in an harmonious way and create order out of chaos. In the late 1960s and early 1970s there were trade wars going on within Canada between the provinces. This legislation and the resulting marketing agencies which were set up created order out of that chaos. It brought a level of stability to this nation for producers in the poultry sector. The poultry farmers of Canada were here on Friday with their counterparts in the dairy industry, which operates under different legislation, to defend that legislation and ensure that the government does not trade it away.
It is also unique in that each producer was assigned a quota for a system of planned production, a system of planned production that ensured that Canadian consumers had adequate supplies of high quality foods at a reasonable price. They had some of the best production in the world with no shortages of supply, no chaos at the farm gate level. The processors had a reasonable return for their efforts and unjustified increases in price did not take place.
These organizations had to work under government supervision at both federal and provincial levels. There were two classes of orders and regulations that had to be prior approved by the supervisory body, the National Products Marketing Council. Any change in price had to be substantiated by the cost of production formula.
The over-all annual global allocation also had to have prior approval. It was a system that not only worked well for the producers of this country but ensured the continuing share for each province. The poorer provinces of Atlantic Canada certainly had a level of stability and an alleviation of fear about their operations. Their operations could not be wiped out by a couple of van loads of eggs from other provinces dumped on their markets to depress the prices. It also provided a level of income which they had not seen for years and years.
In February 1972 I bought eggs at 19 cents a dozen at the same time as those eggs were selling at a supermarket in Toronto for 56 cents a dozen. The production cost
for that product was a minimum of 38 cents a dozen. No wonder there was chaos in the marketplace.
This act brought stability that has lasted for 20 years. Now it is threatened and may be traded away. We can be proud as Canadians that we were able to develop such a system envied by producers in other parts of the world, not only from the United States, whose farmers were on the hill on Friday supporting us in our efforts, but farmers from Europe and other nations. They wanted to help us defend a system being threatened by the forces of transnational corporations who want to destroy the most sophisticated system in the world. It has not contributed to world surpluses. Yet we have not once seen the government come to the defence of these systems which have been under a concerted attack in the media, an attack that started on the floor of this House in October 1990 as a result of a statement made by the Minister for International Trade, an attack that has continued to this day in the media.
In fact, at 6.30 last night on one of our television networks here in Canada, a former negotiator of this government, who negotiated the free trade agreement, stated that these boards are bad for the country, bad for the consumers and should be done away with.
He was bad for this country.

Absolutely. Look what he did to us in the free trade agreement. Now he is having second thoughts. The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands says he was bad for the country. Now he is having second thoughts. He finally woke up and he is realizing this. Now he is targeting the poor farmers of this nation who provide us with such ample supplies of food.
It is obvious that these statements are a reflection on the government's true intent to end these systems that have not received one cent in government subsidies since they were established. They provided adequate supplies of top quality food, the best quality food of any country in the world, at a reasonable cost to consumers. The price setting mechanisms for these agencies and the production targets of course, as I mentioned earlier, have to be prior approved through regulation by the National Farm Products Marketing Council and receive the blue star approval of Privy Council. Thus the interests of the processors, the producers and the consumers are protected.
February 24, 1992

Government Orders
I was shocked on February 12 when the Minister of National Revenue announced an export tax on tobacco. There is quite a story behind this. In this House in the last few days of the previous government we brought in an amendment to amend the National Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act to include tobacco and tobacco products, a simple amendment just to add those words.
A member of the Official Opposition at the time stood up and refused unanimous consent, even though thousands of tobacco farmers were protesting on the Hill. That refusal came from the Official Opposition benches at that time. Then the letter from the Leader of the Official Opposition-

On a point of order, Mr. Speaker. I think the hon. member is making a well reasoned speech but he just made an allegation that a member of the opposition refused unanimous consent. My hon. friend knows that there is no way in the world that he can back up that statement and I think it should be struck from the record.

Mr. Speaker, on that point of order, if you go back in all of our precedents dealing with this question, you will find that a member has a perfect right to say in this Chamber that the nay came from a certain side. He does not have a right, however, to say who gave the nay. For the minister to stand up and raise that as a point of order draws attention to the fact that it was at the time the Official Opposition that refused.

That of course is completely specious and my hon. friend knows it. I will be glad to wait around to give him time to look that word up in the dictionary. It is absolutely improper to reflect upon who said yea or nay in a vote or to refuse unanimous consent. My hon. friend knows it. My hon. friend is an experienced member. He is in full flight in his speech. He is on the front bench of his party, which may be easy to do these days. I think my hon. friend knows better than to reflect and make an allegation like that. I would suggest that his speech would be better phrased if he left that kind of citation out of it.

Before making a ruling, Mr. Speaker, I think it is very easy to check Hansard of the day and to check that it was on the other side of the House where the nay came from.
As my hon. member mentioned, we do not mention names but we do know where the nay came from and where the unanimous consent was not given.
There has been no minister here all afternoon to listen to this important debate. Now a minister trounces in to raise a point of order. That is how interested they are in the farmers of this country.
A phoney point of order.
Correct.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I think that hon. members on all sides were able to convey their message and I ask the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex to return to the debate.

Mr. Speaker, I want to make it very clear that I did not name the member who refused to give consent, nor the constituency he came from.
I believe Hansard will speak for itself if we look that up. I was present in the House at the time.
Less than two months later, the Leader of the Official Opposition at the time sent a letter to the Ontario Tobacco Marketing Board dated August 17 or August 19, it does not really matter. It assured its members that if they formed the government, it would give them their tobacco marketing agency. There is no tobacco marketing agency yet today.
The suggestion that they are on the side of the farmer has to be closely examined, but I want to just go on to the announcement of February 12 and the export tax. To put a tax on the export of tobacco-the purest tobacco of any country in the world with less tar, chemical and nicotine content of any country in the world-will simply destroy the export markets.
Today I received a call from three growers in my riding who immediately realized the damage that has been done to their industry. Bill Thuss and Tony Sleagers of RR3, Strathroy and Gene Vineue of RR2, Strathroy advised me that one of the major tobacco processing companies in Canada, RJ.R. MacDonald Inc. is no longer purchasing tobacco for export markets as a result of this tax.

February 24, 1992
Government Orders
It will in fact destroy those export markets and destroy jobs here in Canada. It will force the countries purchasing tobacco to buy inferior products that contain more tar, nicotine and other chemicals than our Canadian product does.
I ask this government to reverse its position. It is simply not acceptable. It is a further nail in the coffin of this industry in Canada. Those countries will be forced to buy from another market and buy a product even more injurious to their health than Canada's tobacco.
I also ask the government to stop delaying tactics regarding a marketing agency for apples. I know the original act calls for the government to establish these marketing agencies through proclamation when it is satisfied, following plebiscites or declarations, by Lieutenant-Governor in Council or by other means, that the majority of producers in Canada or regions of Canada are in favour of such an agency.
The words "by other means" according to the Department of Justice interpretation I received in 1974 could be a petition by producers. What is the delay? Will this government accept a petition by producers to get the apple marketing agency under way? An agency is required to stop the importation of products grown under very, very cheap labour in other parts of the world. These products have been imported to Canada and are destroying the orchards of the producers who own them.
These products are perhaps treated with chemicals, herbicides and pesticides that are banned in Canada. We have a zero level of tolerance on these imported goods. How can the Canadian consumers expect to have quality products if we have one set of standards and the government allows importation of other products treated with chemicals that are not allowed in Canada?
I want to go just a little bit further. I believe this government intends to destroy the agencies we have. Page 119 of the free trade agreement under definitions chicken and chicken products means chicken or capons, live or viscerous and chicken parts, and so on. It goes on to point out that without limiting the generality of subparagraph 1, there are 13 different types of further processed chicken that are not considered to be chicken. All they have to do is process it in the United States: chicken Kiev, chicken breaded Kiev, chicken cordon bleu, chicken breaded cordon bleu, and so on. Now the
door is wide open for further processed products. Yet we have an agency that is going to be destroyed.
I am very concerned about the legislation before us today. I hope I have laid the ground work and legislative history of this act and why it was brought in. It is an act of this House that may be disembowelled by the actions at GATT because the amendments will allow the agency to be set up to collect levies for research and promotion. Is this a set-up for when these agencies lose their effectiveness under the GATT negotiations? Is this what is happening? Does the government intend to disembowel these agencies; take away their powers to establish a system of planned production to market their products across this nation; open the door to products that are produced in other countries under a different set of standards and regulations than they are here in Canada? I have to wonder.
Although they could carry on as agencies, they would have no powers of pricing, establishing quotas or providing any degree of stability to primary producers.
Of course under the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act, the import controls come from the Import Export Control Act. It has worked very well over the years. It is administered by another department. It does not come under the jurisdiction of Agriculture Canada. If there is a shortage of a product developed here in Canada, they are allowed to bring in a specified amount of the product.
I should point out that when these original agencies were set up, the quotas were established to reflect the level of production of the previous five years for that particular province or the individual producer involved. The amount of imports was set up on the same basis of the average amount of imports allowed into this country over the previous five years. What could be fairer than that?
Under article XI of the GATT, if a country has its production established under restrictions, those same restrictions shall apply to imports. Consequently I think it has been a very fair system and I am very fearful that this piece of legislation will go hand in hand with the government's intent to sell those producers down the tubes at the GATT. That will put us not into an interprovincial trade war, but into a multinational trade war that will threaten to destroy this country, our standard of living and all of rural Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to join the debate on Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
On the surface the bill would enable the establishment of a national agency that hopefully will have the authority to collect levies on domestic and imported products to support research and development to help our farmers. Perhaps it is difficult to argue against that. However, can we trust this government?
Only recently we have seen a series of actions on the part of this government which make this bill look like a charade, make-up, and camouflage. Why is that? Very recently we heard the debate about the GATT proposal that would require Canada to abandon the import controls it now uses to protect dairy, egg and poultry farmers from cheap imports and replace them with a system of tariffication. That is not acceptable to the egg, dairy and poultry farmers.
This GATT proposal is most definitely a consequence of the pressure being placed by the United States on Canada. Shall we resist it? Shall we resist it with all our efforts? I submit we should.
What is at stake in this GATT proposal is the survival of the supply management system, the marketing boards that in essence provide a stable income and fair return on the cost of the labour and industry of our farmers. This system provides Canadians with a steady supply of
Government Orders
quality foods now and in the future and ensures an orderly system that spreads opportunities for all from coast to coast.
At stake, under this GATT proposal, is the viability of a $10 billion industry and 100,000 jobs. It affects farmers, their families and other communities for they are the businesses that supply farmers and the processing plants that rely on the raw products from the farmers. If you kill the egg, dairy, poultry industry you kill many more. There is a domino effect on the other industries in the country. Ultimately, the consumers will be affected because the very survival of a self-sufficient national food system is put into peril.
Were this sad scenario to occur, and I hope it does not, we would not be able to preserve our arable lands that are environmentally friendly.
In Manitoba, and across the country, we have seen a steady rise in the number of those who must receive welfare to survive. We have seen a steady rise in the number of unemployed. They would like to find jobs but they cannot find one. In Manitoba there has already been an increase in emigration, in the exit of people from my home province of Manitoba to other provinces. Therefore, when we heard about the GATT proposal it was yet another blow which created a sense of pessimism and gloom, as has also been indicated by the National Dairy Council of Canada. At this juncture, allow me to read a news report from the Winnipeg Free Press of Saturday, February 22. It is titled: "Couple Fear for Future of Dairy Farms". It reads in part:
"Wayne and Teri Fuchs are expecting their first child but they don't know whether their future son or daughter will grow up on a dairy farm. The couple, who milk 25 cows near Steinbach, are worried that a new international trade agreement being negotiated in Geneva will set off a chain of events that will force them off the farm".
That is fear, fear on the part of Canadians who now have farms. They fear for themselves today and they fear for their children tomorrow. So Canada must fear for itself.
Shall we allow this government to sacrifice a primary industry to its unfettered free market dogma? The answer from Canadians is an unequivocal no.

The farmers at the farm rally last Friday asked this government that they be allowed to stay on their farmlands for another 125 years. Let us allow it to happen.

I must say that food is a social glue in any society. Our farmers deserve their survival and deserve our support.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate this opportunity to speak on this bill.

Grain growers, poultry producers, dairy farmers, they are all fighting together the position the government took on GATT originally and which it has moved away from but also are trying to bolster the position it claims to have now.
They are trying to make sure that the negotiations the government is having at GATT will not devastate supply management and supply managed marketing boards. They are not feeling very happy with the position the government has taken.
In these amendments to the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act, the government is doing a number of things, none of which is going to improve the act particularly.
First of all, it is repaying a political debt to certain groups of producers. It is continuing to divide the farmers. If one group of farmers does not say what the government thinks it wants to hear, it will try to organize another group of farmers. That group will be given some responsibility and the government will expect to hear the answer from it.
The government is not interested in hearing one single voice from the farmers when it can hear a wide variety of voices and opinions. If it gets advice that it does no like from one major group, it can always go out and create another group. That group will tell it exactly what it wants to hear. Then those farmers who have stated the government's point of view will have some ability to operate within the system. That is the payment of the debt.
